reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Increasing self-resilience of the persons with functional difficulties by providing prosthetics and creating inclusive protective environments through community and beneficiary participation

description.narrative:
The proposed project will form a complementary part of HIHFAD on-going comprehensive supports to survivors of ERW and other conflict-related and nonrelated injuries (mobile outreach service, fixed rehabilitation service, prosthetic service, inclusion mainstreaming and peers counselling) with multiple partners. In addition, the project emphasis on participation of the beneficiaries themselves and the community members to harness inclusive and protective environments in the target communities through establishment of community networks on inclusion and case management.
Building on HIHFAD’s previous success in harnessing self-reliance and self-confidence among the most marginalized group, the proposed project aims at increasing self-resilience of the persons with disabilities and creating inclusive and protective environments through community and beneficiary participation. Through three inter-connected components 1) Benefiting and empowering people with amputations directly through prosthetic supports in Northwest Syria. 2) Enhancing community-based inclusive approach and protection among the local communities and local NGOs through creating community inclusion networks. 3) Providing customized supports of their choices to the persons with functional disabilities through case managements
1-Provison of 200 prosthesis in Albab city (8 months) This project is a co-fund to operate Al Bab Center for additional 8 months between November 2020 and June 2021(the center is funded till Oct 2020 by HALO Trust)During 8 months, the center will install 200 prosthesis. The beneficiaries will be selected from HIHFAD beneficiary list or through referral channels, after determining their ability to receive a prosthetic limb based on their K-level(a rating system used to indicate a person's rehabilitation potential). The selected beneficiaries will undertake required physical rehabilitation at the HIHFAD rehabilitation centre prior to receiving prosthetics. Transportation will be provided for the beneficiaries in need throughout the whole process.
2- Enhancing community-based inclusive approach (12 months) The project will target 14 community, 1 inclusion network will be established in each community consisting of people with and without functional difficulties. They will first undertake inclusion training for themselves, and later, they will actively engage in planning and conducting of the following tasks: - Plan and provide training and awareness sessions on inclusion of people with disabilities. - Identify and refer people with disabilities - Become an agent of advocacy in their communities for rights of people with disabilities -Plan and conduct community events of their choices. In addition, the project will conduct evidence-collection activity to compile lessons learned from community-based inclusive approach. 3 - Case Management and Protection Assistance: 300 beneficiaries and their families among the most vulnerable households will benefit through case management, offering PSS sessions, protection assistance, referrals, specialized service and access to socio-economic activities. The beneficiaries can request their choices of supports, which will be assessed and verified by the committees (HIHFAD staff and community members). This could include items to immediately reduce constrains faced by the most vulnerable households or more resilience-focused choices such as skill training, livelihood kits accelerated education. An average value of 180USD per person will be allocated for multi-purpose assistance through case management. The coronavirus pandemic expands an existing gap in the provision of this project services.This project was designed taking into consideration the expanded needs. The mentioned activities will take place in Aleppo/Afrin/Afrin- Jandairis- Sharan, Aleppo / Alabab/Albab, Aleppo /Jabel Samman/Atareb, Idleb/Harim/Dana,Idleb- Maaret Tamsrin

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision GBV Services through Mobile Teams in Northwest Syria

description.narrative: Maram Foundation will work through this project to reduce GBV effect by targeting vulnerable and conflict-affected IDPs in13 widows' camps in Idleb, Al Dana (Atma, Aqrabat, Qah, Babesqa, Deir Hassan), as well as the surrounding camps, 23500 BNFs (7500 girls, 12000 women,1800 boys amp 2200 men) including 1446 families (4865 of widows). The provision of GBV services in these areas will respond to critical issues, mainly discrimination, violence, economic exploitation, movement restrictions, SEA, forced and early marriage those widows, girls and PWDs exposed to, according to the data collected. It will also focus on strengthening elements of the preparedness and response to the COVID-19 pandemic as well as to adapt activities according to the GBV SC guidance note on COVID19. In addition, this project will be complementary with existing projects in the targeted areas (MF WGSS centres: Jasmin 2amp4). MF conducts all activities in close coordination with local actors, and according to the Guidance Note: Mitigating Protection Risks in IDP Sites, many stakeholders share the responsibility of ensuring the protection of affected populations throughout the entire life cycle of a site /Feb2019/. MF has running projects in the targeted locations and two WGSS centres (the first WGSSs in this area) including midwives who provide simple services of RH. MF also ensures coordination with organizations working in the same region and/or protection, GBV actors. MF is conducting activities in 9 widows’ camps through WGSSs ongoing project since Jan 2020, with permission renewed on monthly basis. During May 2020 an assessment took place, recommendations mentioned the necessity of Safe Spaces inside widows’ camps (Annex 3), which include lessons learned and solutions suggested. The project will be implemented on stages: 1, coordinating with the camp administration in order to secure a place for the project activities that take into account the confidentiality amp safety of the activities. If no secured place, MF will create a tent as WGSS. 2, An elected committee of women amp girls including PWDs amp elderly women (in each camp), is going to participate in decision-making to determine the identity of the place, the type of activities, empowerment topics and future modality of their lifestyle. 3, 13 of mobile teams will be implementing the project’s activities, each team consists of a case manager who will provide CM both in-person and remotely, according to the COVID19 response stage outlined in the GBV SC guidance note of COVID-19, Also, PSS worker and female facilitator for each camp, and another male facilitator will be targeting men amp boys who live near the widows' camps, local authorities and councils. 4, MF will conduct empowerment courses for women, to enhance economic capacity, in order to rely on themselves, especially sewing, so they will have a role in producing masks as a kind of preparation to respond to the spread of the epidemic. 5, MF WGSSs will conduct training for medical workers and first responders in order to respond to GBV cases, especially in light of the spread of COVID19. Also, training for workers on PFA, GBV, PSEA referral mechanism and will focus on the activities that enhance the well-being of staff. MF has full access to widows’ camps, with solid relationships with local communities, camps management and IDP representation committees (Annex 8).In September 2019, GBV SC recommended MF as a reputable NGO with vast experience in protection and Gender-Based Violence programs, and proven accessibility in northwest Syria.MF has been identified and recommended by the GBV SC as a reputable NGO with vast experience in protection and GBV programs, and proven accessibility in NW Syria. Also, are firmly committed to the global fight to eradicate SEA and have 4 technical acting members within the UN-OCHA PSEA meetings.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Promote and Strengthen Community-Based protection interventions and Providing Individually Life-Saving Protection Services in NWS.

description.narrative: Starting from the priorities identified by the protection cluster and sub-clusters, and as per the findings of the need’s assessments conducted in the last period, SEMA, under the support of SCHF, seeks to provide life-saving protection services in the following two components: 1- CP Services: implemented by SEMA and SANAD which includes the following: Continuity of ongoing activities and projects that include existing case management teams and CFS at Afrin and A’zaz districts, which are currently under the support of SCHF through USSOM till the end of July. As SEMA, in partnership with SANAD organization, aims to continue operating the existed two Amal centers in Moaz Abo Mehdi Hospital and introduce CP case management, awareness, identification and referral through the static and mobile teams, where SANAD team will provide Special need rehabilitation program (SNR) for CWD, and their parents. AMAL center in Sharan will continue provision its specialized services with expansion in adding a safe space for PSS activities and 2 outreach teams witch will provide awareness raising sessions ,recreational activities and identification and referral for at risk CP cases. Establishment of CP services focusing on specialized service at Al-Bab Sub-district, where a new CFS will be established and case management, referral, PSS and awareness sessions’ activities will be delivered through static and mobile teams. Case management activities will continue to address CP concerns including worst forms of child labor, neglect, child marriage and CAAFAG in addition to those aggravated by COVID-19 such as family separation or children left without their primary caregiver due to illness, hospitalization or bereavement/death of a parent or primary caregivers, risk of neglect, domestic violence, exploitation, and psychological distress. SEMA will continue mobilizing its Health, Nutrition, Physiotherapy, and MHPSS services which formed a strong internal referral system in addition to the effective external referral system for specialized and nonspecialized services already exist. More details about the activities of SANAD and the added value for partnership with them is uploaded in "Documents" tab. Already existed CPN (and a new one will be established in Albab), will be utilized to be able to raise the awareness of affected communities on CP concerns, awareness about seriousness of health, contagion risks of COVID–19 outbreak and safety measures and precautions. Supervision mechanism will continue supporting Case managers in providing safe, ethical, and competent services. SEMA team will continue in contributing in CPM as a member of the taskforce. During the implementation of all activities precaution measures will be taken as per WHO guidelines, where teams will be trained and provided with PPE. In case of COVID-19 spreads activities will be conducted online through WhatsApp groups. 2- Gender Based Violence: Implemented by HRO from the beginning of July. SEMA in partnership with Hope Revival Organization, the sub-implementing partner, aims to maintain and enhance the safe access of GBV case management and Women and Girl’s Safe Spaces (WGSS) of affected women and girls especially those with special needs in both already functioning centers is Jisr Ash Shugur Community and Kafr Jales Community. Life Skills, awareness-raising through outreach (entry point to identify GBV cases, risks, and needs), case management, empowerment, training of GBV and non GBV actors, and safety audits are some of the key activities in addition to working with existing community committees and focusing on community engagement and to take part in designing and implementation. More details about the HRO activities and the added value for partnership with them is also uploaded in "Documents" tab.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhance access to life-saving community-based protection services (GBV MA) for IDPs and host communities in four locations in northwest Syria.

description.narrative: WSA runs three WGSSs in Bennish, KafrTakarim, and Kaferlucin in Idleb, NW Syria, and plans to continue implementing activities through providing protection services for women and girls affected by the crisis, including GBV survivors and persons affected by war injuries and mild physical disabilities. These are backed by Casualty Data Collection that is going to be shared with IMSMA and to help in identifying cases and needs for planning. Besides the three mentioned locations, our partner NAS will conduct RE and VDC services in Idlib sub-district. COVID-19 awareness messages -and prevention procedures- will be put into consideration in all activities. The WGSS in Bennish, provides protection services for WampG, in line with the UNFPA Guidelines, including WampG with a mild physical disability. The center contributes to the promotion of services and measures of MA and quality GBV services providing appropriate services to prevent and reduce the risks of GBV, ERW, and COVID-19 in the mentioned location. The center offers child care to improve access for women with little children, besides an outreach service through trained mobile teams that can reach beneficiaries who cannot come, or have no access, to the center. According to the latest developments regarding the global pandemic of Coronavirus, the WHO guidelines, and following the guidance note on the provision of GBV and MA services during the COVID-19 Pandemic, developed by the GBV and MA SCs WSA has begun to provide the services by reducing the number of beneficiaries inside the centers and increase the outreach activities, taking into account the recommended prevention measures. In terms of the other two locations (in KafrTakarim and Kaferlucin), MA service will be provided, including RE and VDC, plus referring cases in need of individual assistance. These services are going to be provided through fixed and outreach activities. Indoor activities: Train teams on how to prevent COVID-19 and RE communicating messages to beneficiaries (IDPs, host community, and humanitarian actors), casualty surveys, GBV, and RE. Provide specialized GBV services and CM, in addition to group and specialized individual PSS. 2 CM workers will follow up with the WampG-GBV survivors- including survivors of ERW accidents and affected by war injuries and mild physical disabilities. In addition to providing direct support service and referrals to other services according to the referral paths that are shared by the sub-clusters, and service mapping through coordination with actors in the area, continuously updated. Provide vocational training (sewing) for the most vulnerable WampG. Case management principles to be followed, privacy, informed, a survivor code. All case-related files are kept confidentially in a locked cabinet and are periodically destroyed after e-copies are held secured, where only the CW and the T-supervisor can reach them. Preventive activities, such as life skills (My safety my wellbeing) and recreational activities, young mother’s club in coordination with SRD and CARE. Distribution of awareness GBV (GBV-SC package), RE (MASC messages), Covid19 (WHO tools) brochures. Refer cases/victims in need of individual assistance (VA). Outreach activities: Provide emergency response for WampG: PFA, CM and referral, registration for GBV cases, and VDC for ERW survivors. Conduct awareness sessions for Covid19, using posters in the camps. Training sessions for non-specialized service providers in the field of GBV, RE, and Covid19 prevention measures, with a focus on health staff, on best practices in dealing with GBV and ERW survivors.

title.narrative: Providing essential general protection and child protection services to conflict-affected girls, women, boys, and men in Idleb, Ariha and Jisr-Ash- Shugur

description.narrative: Syria Relief SR aims to continue providing General Protection and Child Protection services in south and west Idleb, after starting delivering those services in north Idleb under the 1st RA 2020. The project aims to deliver planned services to most vulnerable Girls, Boys, Women and Men GBWM in Idleb, Ariha and Jisr-Ash- Shugur districts through 4 static community centres CCs within 4 relatively densely populated communities in addition to 4 mobile units. SR will ensure the services are accessible by PwDs and will consider all possible precautious measures (social distancing and using the PPE) and Cluster guidelines related to adapting Protection services delivery modalities in light with COVID-19, to ensure the safety of staff and beneficiaries and avoid causing harm (see attached SR COVID-19 Response Plan). The services will be delivered during 12 months starting from 1st of Jul-20, addressing the identified Protection and CP needs of targeted individuals. The Overall Project Objective is designed to provide integrated protection and CP services and coordinate closely with local service providers from other sectoral services (FSL amp Early Recovery, WASH, and Health-Nutrition actors) to facilitate access of persons with specific needs to those services. The outcome of the proposed intervention will be conflict-affected and most vulnerable GBWM, including PwD, have a better understanding of their rights and better resilience through benefitting from legal Protection, Protection and Child Protection services. This Outcome has been informed by the ASOs 1 and 2 as outlined in the 2020 1st Standard Allocation. SR aims at the continuation of protection activities within areas of operation. Besides, the protection teams will extend their reach into new subdistricts in Idleb governorate rated 4, 5 or 6/ 6 in the severity scale. Protection services are intended to provide a package of essential preventive and responsive services to affected Host communities, IDPs and Returnees through expanding the capacity of mobile outreach teams, reactivating Ariha centre (CFS), and launching new Protection activities in parallel with the existing Education activities that SR implements in Jisr-Ash- Shugur. The project is designed to reactivate Ariha static facility that SR evacuated in Oct-20 and add 1facility in Korin, 1 in Jisr-Ash-Shugur and the fourth facility in Hanbushiyeh. The 4 static facilities will be community hubs through which SR can identify and respond to most affected populations. 4 mobile units will be attached to those centres to reach out PwDs or those practising voluntary quarantine so they cannot visit the centres. The gender-mixed mobile units will also deliver the project services within 8 neighbouring communities. The proposed CCs and mobile units will provide many general protection and child protection services including awareness-raising about legal protection, general protection and CP concerns. SR Teams will also provide case management and IPA to the identified most vulnerable GWBM. PSS will be delivered to girls and boys. Besides, parents will have the opportunity to join positive parenting skills sessions. Training about HLP/CSD and CP will be delivered to concerned humanitarian workers to ensure they are well capacitated. Community-based Protection committees will be supported. Furthermore, the Protection Teams will be part of the current Cluster taskforces and collect data related to Protection Monitoring and Child Protection Situational Monitoring surveys. Emergency focal points will be assigned to contribute to Cluster efforts in coordinating the Protection response. Protection services will provide a secure and supportive environment, building on existing capacities within the local communities and expanding the population of SR response team. SR Protection Teams will implement all Project activities directly with support from SR Turkey Office.

title.narrative: Enhancing access to GBV prevention services in Western rural of Aleppo.

description.narrative:
The project endeavors to implement complemented activities in the humanitarian field in western rural of Aleppo province. This intervention will make contribution towards strengthening community-based protection interventions and life-saving protection assistance depending on the expansion of the activities of two existing protection centers WGSS specialized in GBV in Atareb and Kafr Karmin villages and conducting of outreach activities. The project will target women, men, older women, girls, boys, and people with disabilities and include implementation of the following activities: - Forming of two mobile teams in order to provide of psychological first aid (PFA), information/awareness, case management, GBV services, referrals to GBV services and other services. The teams will cover the Daret Azza and Atareb sub-district in rural Aleppo in addition to the surrounding camps.(every sub-team will consist of two mobile teams, two social workers and case management workers). - Providing support for case management activities (Case fund) for 100 survivors. This assistance will be provided in kind and cash and the amount estimated for each beneficiary is 100 USD. Based on Cash Assistance in GBV Case Management Guidance Note June, 2019.By GBV-sub cluster. - Engaging women and girls in making COVID-19 prevention IEC material “masks” where the women survivors and volunteers are not only contributing to protect the health of essential workers, they are also feeling empowered and valued. - Increasing availability of remote staff well-being services to support to all team members and keep them Productive by undertake a range of activities to improve their health and wellbeing. Ina addition to, collect, analyse, interpret, evaluate and present data regarding protection and wellbeing activities for reporting and decision-making purposes.
This intervention will support 14525 beneficiaries affected by the Syrian crisis (2942 men,5714 women, 2214 boys and 3655 girls) in Atareb and Daret Azza - sub-districts by promoting their accessibility to the protection assistance significantly. The project is designed to fit and be flexible to deal with conditions of constant changes and continuous of flows of IDPs who move between several locations. Also, the project team will ensure data protection, confidentiality at all stages, protocols of information sharing and acquiring informed consent from beneficiaries. The project activities will be in line with Protection Cluster Recommendations, SOPs, Inclusive COVID-19 response - NWS Disability - TWG on Inclusion Guidance Note April 2020 and GBV SC guidance note on GBV service provision in the time of COVID-19 such as Hand sanitizing when conducting the sessions/ Gathering of five beneficiaries per session and social distance/Measure the temperature for each beneficiary as a precaution/ Plan has been put for online sessions/ Put awareness posters about Corona disease during sessions.
MASRRAT is providing GBV service in Jabal Saman district by two WGSS centers in coordination with Ihsan and SRD. MASRRAT is a member of the protection cluster since 6 years ago and a focal point in Jebel Seman district to provide GBV services. This project will complement the ongoing UNFPA project through covering of more area of intervention in Jebel Samaan ,where the two teams will work together under the same management and technical support, also the project will support the centers by vocational activity. Each outreach team will be accompanied by a case manager who identifies the cases and coordinates with the GBV technical supervisor on UNFPA project to receive the cases in WGSS centers.

title.narrative: Delivery and integration of protection services to most at-risk and marginalized women and girls in greater Al Bab Sub-district.

description.narrative: The project will address the protection needs of both IDP and Host Communities in Albab subdistrict, northern Aleppo as a continuation of funding for Women and Girls Safe Space (WGSS) and affiliated community based outreach team. The WGSS started operating September 2018 funded by SCHF and continued until today with good acceptance from local community. SRD provides integrated protection activities within health facilities and stand-alone Women and Girls Safe Spaces (WGSS), providing response activities through a case management approach and a solid referral pathway in Albab city. A holistic and intensive model of case management will be utilized in the currently functional Women and Girls Safe Space in Al Bab city to enhance the resilience of survivors and vulnerable women and girls, specifically during COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, SRD provides capacity building, empowerment, preventive services, and community-based outreach activities as an entry point to reach more vulnerable groups. SRD will continue to provide integrated GBV and PSS services in an accessible health/protection delivery points located in different affiliated communities to Al Bab. The protection team will reach a target of 10,056 individuals (586 men, 5,762 women, 1,050 boys, 2,658 girls) and addressing vulnerabilities that are related to PWDs, elderly, men, women, boys and girls with high risks identified in each targeted community during 12 months of implementation.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Facilitating access to clean and safe drinking water to conflict-affected communities in Idleb 2020 - 2021

description.narrative:
GOAL proposes to support 16 Water Stations (WSs) managed by 3 Water Units (WUs) in Idleb Governorate to enhance their capacity to meet increased local water demand owing to population displacements, outlined in section 2 of this proposal. The aim of the action is to ensure access to reliable, safe and clean drinking water by conflict-affected communities including host and displaced populations in the northern sub-districts of Idleb Governorate. This will be done through infrastructure rehabilitation and repairs, training and coaching to WUs and subordinated WSs staff, and water quality management. Complementary to this, COVID-19 adapted hygiene promotion sessions and COVID-19 community led action (CLA) sessions will be carried out. The project is a continuation of the ongoing OCHA Syria Cross-border Humanitarian Fund (SCHF) funded project (TUR-19/3559/SA2/WASH/INGO/14498) that is currently due to end on 08 July, and is pending modification request approval for extension until 31 July 2020.
The proposed action will enable approximately 180,369 people living in the targeted WSs’ catchment areas to regularly access adequate quantities of clean and safe drinking water, piped directly to households (HHs). Approximately 35 litres/person/day (LPD) will be pumped to HHs. This is in accordance with current WASH Cluster COVID-19 guidance. Additionally, 3,150 people attending GOAL distributions under other projects will be reached with COVID-19 adapted hygiene promotion sessions and 350 individuals will participate in COVID-19 CLA sessions through this action. In total 3,500 people will benefit from hygiene activities.
GOAL’s wider WASH programme, including the current active version of the proposed project, has undergone an intensive COVID-19 preparation and adaption process that will enable GOAL to continue providing these essential WASH services in the case of a COVID-19 outbreak.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of Emergency WASH Services to Informal Camps- Settlements and Health Facilities in Idleb and Aleppo Governorates

description.narrative:
Qatar Charity (QC) with implementing partner Ihsan Relief and Development (IRD) will provide 50,730 individuals with WASH services. The project’s interventions are designed to continue providing the services of project TUR-19/3559/RA3/WASH/NGO/14904 in the two main interventions: Continue in providing Emergency WASH services for the displaced persons in informal settlements located in Dana Sub-district due to the influx of IDPs from Al Mara in December 2019. Continue in providing WASH services for eight health facilities in Dana, Atareb, Daret Azza , Shamarine and Azaz Sub-districts. The project will provide 13,380 IDP's living in 21 informal settlements and camps in Idleb and Aleppo governorates with all basic WASH services considering COVID-19 mitigation measures, by the provision of adequate drinking water via water trucking (35ltr/PD/pp) while constantly assuring the quality of the water through chlorination and tested, storage water tanks, solid waste removal, provision waste containers, de-sludging latrine septic tanks. This project also will hold segregated sessions for men, women, and children to raise personal and environmental hygiene awareness in general and to apply prevention measures of COVID-19. The project activities have been modified from the previous one in order to be in line with the COVID-19 guidance of the WASH Cluster proposed and revised interventions/activities as the following: Increasing the water trucking quantity from 25 liters to 35 liters per person per day to allow extra handwashing. Installation of additional extra water tanks. Increasing the frequency of solid waste collection and distribute additional garbage bins. Distribution of Latrine Cleaning Materials Kit(Liquid chlorine , Liquid soap ,sprayer, Flash. Distribution hygiene promotion materials such as posters and banner in camps at WASH facility and highly visible locations.
As response of COVID-19 eight health facilities will be served with the WASH services’ either running cost or maintenance cost as the following: Repair/ renovate existing WASH facilities including replacement of dysfunctional handwashing basins, taps, showers, toilet seats. Provision safe and adequate water . Installation of soap container per each handwashing unit. Installation of handwashing units Soap procurement and refilling. Provision of desludging or connect to existing wastewater collection if needed. Provision of solid waste collection, separation, and disposal services with attention to sanitary disposal system Support WASH facilities cleaning. Spraying and facility disinfection with liquid chlorine. The project's interventions have put strong emphasis and providing emergency WASH service that can meet the different needs of men, women, boys, and girls with full consideration of the specific needs of the most vulnerable groups women, children, elderlies and people with a disability, in providing the project's services (latrines, washing facilities, etc). Female staff will be recruited to facilitate communication and consultation between the project’s staff with women and girls. The project will hire women and men and provide them with cleaning tools and materials to clean latrines in the targeted camps to sustain those latrines and keep them clean for use by the whole people in the targeted locations.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of Life-saving humanitarian WASH and seasonal NFI assistance for the most vulnerable People in North West Syria

description.narrative:
This project is designed to support the most vulnerable IDPs with WASH services and winterization NFIs in Idleb camps by providing clean water, water tanks, hygiene kits, hygiene awareness, garbage containers and latrines as well as supporting the same targeted camps with heating fuel through restricted value E-vouchers. Total beneficiaries is1622 HHs, 9622 individualls(2310 W, 2211 M, 2215 G, 2886 B) as following Camps: Maaret Tmasreen (AlHamra:291,AlFesal,Al-Ajaj 214) Dana (AlMadina 500,Huzefa bin Al-Yaman153,Brdghli 100) Harim (AlMatar Road 80) Salqeen (AlRefatyah100) As targeted camps are already supported by Takaful till July, so, the continues of providing services is critical in saving individuals lives, un addition to benefiting from pre-provided supplies. The project will achieve its objectives through a combination of two main interventions: WASH: -In the first 3 months We will construct collection tanks in the camps and connect it with water sources by establishment a water supply network from the available sources to the high-water tanks in addition to linking it to the sub-tanks via a network within the camp ground for the following camps (bin Al-Yaman, Brdghli.Al-Matar, AlRefatyah) in order to increase sustainability and enviromental preservation, and during this period, we will provide water trucking 40 liter per person per day. In (Al-Madina, Al-Hamra, Al-Fesal and Al-Ajaj) camps we will provide water trucking due to the inability to connect these camps to water sources for several reasons such as the large distances between camp and the source, necessity of the network passing through private lands or the camp location in high mountainous. -To enhance the ability of the beneficiaries to hygiene, especially with condition of COVID19, we will distribute two hygiene kits for each family in the 2nd month and in 4th month and the contents will be according to cluster guidelines. Also, hygiene promotion sessions will be conducted in targeted camps, through trained mobile team (M,F) about the hygiene, COVID-19 preventions and IEC , taking into account the prevention procedures, social distancing and sterilization. -Then we will work on construction of 244 latrines (122 blocks) according to cluster standards related to COVID-19, gender sensitive by building separated blocks, safe accessible, and its doors provided with locks, latrine for PwD with special arrangements, septic tanks will be desludging every 20 days. During implementation of the project 203 garbage containers will be installed for the waste disposal once each two days for each camp will be implemented.
NFI: At the beginning of winter, the same beneficiaries will be provided with restricted value E-voucher with total value of $180 which was determined to meet HH's winterization needs of 360 liter of fuel and a stove "based on SNFI cluster guidance" by dividing this value into three phases, where a specific balance ($60-$60-$60) will be loaded to HH's voucher at the beginning of each phase. 1622 HHs will be targeted with various fuel types (Kerosene-Diesel– Firewood and Olive pits) and stoves where this diversity will give the opportunities for HH to choose the type of fuel prefer and the related stove from the vendors who prefer, vendors will be selected according to specific criteria. we will conduct a PDM to ensure that the service arrived to the beneficiaries in a smoothly and to measure beneficiaries satisfactory In case of displacement during the implementation, priority will be given to newly IDPs, furthermore, if an urgent problem occurs and there is no possibility to distribute in one of targeted location, we will replace the beneficiaries and choose another beneficiary according to criteria in another location in coordination with SNFI Cluster -Principles of Do No Harm will be applied in all activities through several market visits, distribution monitoring We will coordinate with NGOs and the clusters to avoid any overlap.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Support the people in the north of Syria by providing WASH services

description.narrative:
The project is designed to respond to the WASH needs of 166592 people (Men: 27765, Women: 28321, Girls: 54975, Boys: 55531),(140876 IDPs and 25716 hosted people) with 1421 people of them are people with disabilities, to respond to their protracted needs by ensuring the good access to the sanitation service The men, women, boys, and girls in Dana city are suffering from the poor sanitation infrastructure in the city since the sewage network is covering only 50 – 60 % of the city and it was prepared to serve this small city with a maximum capacity of 16751 people while the city and due to the ongoing crisis witnessed large displacement waves and the number of IDPs touched more than 140,000 IDPs which consist more than 85 % of the population of Dana These terrible figures increased the suffering of the people and the pressure on the already weak infrastructure and made from Dana city one of the most affected areas of Leishmania in northern Syria according to the information of the EWARN and the statement of the medical centers in the area in addition to the notable flood of the wastewater in the public street in all the seasons and especially in the winter which is damaging any humanitarian efforts to respond to the Leishmania cases since the main cause of the problem will remain, and the treatment solutions are useless as long The spreading of Leishmania is not caused by the poor sewage infrastructure only but also it is by the inability of the local council to put well solid waste management in place and this is another factor can increase the threat on the vulnerable people SECD is aiming to solve this long-known problem in the city by undertaking the rehabilitation of the sewage network in the city and supporting the local council to activate good solid waste management which is protecting the people from the expected flood in winter, reducing and eliminating the Leishmania causes and protecting the groundwater from the pollution which considered the main resource of the drinkable water in the city During the project SECD will conduct the following activities: 1-Rehabilitation of the sewer system which includes but not limited to Rehabilitation and extending of Sewer system network (HDPE 30cm diameter ):1770m, - (HDPE 40cm diameter ):1330m,- (HDPE100 cm diameter ):4393m, and Conducting about 70 manholes. 3- undertake Fast and light rehabilitation of the solid waste landfill. 4-Rehabilitation and or /providing of the solid waste truck. 5-Support SWM unit with salaries and fuel for 5 months, and Uniform for the workers, masks, gloves to protect the workers of coronavirus-2019 with ensuring the application of cost recovery system for this activity in the future to achieve the sustainability in this service with Conducting solid waste campaigns to encourage people to participate in this humanitarian effort 7-Conducting hygiene promotion campaigns. 8-Distribution of 3000 hygiene kits (two rounds) for new IDPs which did not receive hygiene kits during the last three months .
SECD will be in close position with the local council, the beneficiaries, the IDPs and the host community and will involve them in all the project stages from the planning till the closure of the project to adhere to the community engagement approach by inviting them to regular FGDs and open all the channels to receive their feedback, complaints, and opinions. the proposed project ensure that the sanitation service would be provided to 7 schools, 4 hospitals, 2 children friendly center,2 Women empowerment centers, and 7 public bakeries. Moreover, 264792 people (188084 IDPs, 76708 Hosted people ) living in (Termanin, Tal Elkaramej, Burdaqly, Sarmada, Hezreh - Hezri, Tilaada, and Dier Hassan) could be considered as indirect beneficiaries since they will benefit from the project because the main outlet sewer of these communities discharged to the main sewer of Dana city which SECD will rehabilitate and replace it

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of sustainable access to clean and safe drinking water for IDPs in Atma camps

description.narrative:
The project activities aim to provide life-saving assistance that assures sustainable and safe access of 91,616 IDPs (17,256 Men, 20,464 Women, 28,998 Boys, 24,898 Girls 13742 PwD) living in Atma camps and informal settlements to clean and safe drinking water services through connecting IDP sites to a new installed drinking water system.
Need ------ Currently, drinking water is being supplied to IDPs living in Atma cluster through water tanks distributed withing the camps with limited storage capacity of the HHs living in the camp and informal settlements. The tanks are being filled by water trucking vehicles that transport the water from the nearby boreholes to the tanks. IDPs take their daily share of water from the water manholes next to the tanks and store it in jerrycans or containers. IDPs, especially the most vulnerable groups such as women, children, the elderly and PwD, face many risks and difficulties while obtaining water. One of the most critical risk is spreading infection with an infectious disease due to crowding at water distribution points, especially with the COVID-19 outbreak. In addition to health risks, there are protection risks that are increased with using water trucking method, especially for women, girls, PwD and children. These developments and causes have created an urgent need to upgrade the water system in IDP sites to provide sustainable solutions that ensure the effective and safe access of IDPs to safe and clean drinking water services.
Intervention --------------- At the beginning of the project, Bonyan Organization will ensure the community engagement through discussion with main stakeholders -including all types of beneficiaries, key informants, and local authorities- to identify locations of water distribution points with considering the initial drawings of the water network. Then Bonyan will develop and sign MoUs with main stakeholders, including 1) Local Authorities, and 2) Humanitarian actors who work in water trucking services in the targeted camps (mainly Global Communities Organization. Based on results of community engagement discussions, technical assessment, and topographic survey, Bonyan will develop detailed technical specifications and scope of work to identify the number of water distribution points and their distancing in every sub-pipe. The distribution points will feed safe drinking water pipes that will be connected to all tents/buildings in the targeted locations. Bonyan will carry out installation works, using a contractual method under supervision of Bonyan engineering unit, as listed here: 1) Pumping Station - A ground water tank, capacity of 300 cubic meter - 4 centrifugal water pumps, power of 15 HP per each - Electric generator, power of 75 KVA - Electrical control panel - Key facilities of the station 2) Water Network - Water network (HDPE pipes and shutoff valves) - Connecting the network to existing nearby boreholes.
Besides that, Bonyan will establish 2 hygiene and awareness promotion teams to conduct and design proper awareness promotion activities that ensure physical distancing, COVID-19 related recommendations, and importance of saving water … etc.
At the end, Bonyan will hand over the project to the community that is representative by engineering office of Local Authorities in Atma Cluster, and provide it with engineering layouts/ drawings, technical specification documents, and maintenance/ expansion instructions of the pumping station and water network.
Bonyan will achieve the project objective through a series of specific activities and processes, taking into account accountability to affected-people, protection mainstreaming and GBV/PSEA, risk analysis and mitigation, tight monitoring and evaluation processes, and effective coordination with all stakeholders, as well as, a coherent exit strategy that contributes to sustainable results of the project.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Delivery of Essential Life-Saving and Life-Sustaining WASH Services in Areas of Return

description.narrative:
The proposed action will provide life-saving and life-sustaining Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) assistance in Ariha and Atareb sub-districts. Targeted sub-districts are home to approximately half of all conflict affected people who returned during early April and are ranked as highest in terms of WASH severity of need by the 2020 Humanitarian Needs Overview (HNO). Planned activities have been developed in close coordination with the WASH cluster and other members with COVID-19 prevention measures incorporated across the program design.
The project will benefit a total of 58,450 conflict-affected people, of which 10,450 are Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and 43,500 are host community members in Ariha City and Jeineh Town (Atareb sub-district). All 47,500 beneficiaries targeted in Ariha are recent returnees, with approx. 3,000 of the 10,500 beneficiaries targeted in Jeineh also recently returned following conflict-related displacement
The action will address critical gaps in access to safe water through rehabilitation works to Jeineh station and essential repairs to Ariha City water stations and existing boreholes completed during the first three months of the action. Provision of operational and maintenance support to water stations will be initiated from July in Ariha and from October in Jeineh (following completion of station rehabilitation works). Field visits by Big Heart WASH Engineers and Focus Group Discussions (FGDs) completed during May have shown that just under half of the Ariha City water network infrastructure was damaged by conflict escalations earlier this year, with replacement pipes required for approximately 15% of the Jeineh network. In response, targeted works to repair sections of the water networks will be completed in both communities during the first three months of the action. Priority will be placed on ensuring schools, health centers and reception centers have adequate access to water during the planning and implementation of water network infrastructure works. This will include the COVID-19 Quarantine Center planned by Violet in Ariha City and the medical points managed by UOSSM and Al AmeenThe creation of tariff systems will be initiated during November with levels of Operation amp Maintenance (OampM) support gradually phased out from February to ensure sustainability and maintain access to affordable safe water beyond the project duration (please see activity 1.1.5 for more detail).
Sanitation services have been assessed and highly targeted upgrades to rainwater drainage systems will be completed in both communities from September through to November 2020.
No selection criteria will be applied to planned water and sewage / rainwater drainage activities which will be delivered at community level to ensure all returnees, host and IDPs in targeted areas benefit from increased access to improved WASH services.
In addition to ensuring access to adequate water and improved rainwater drainage, hygiene promotion and awareness activities will increase understanding of COVID-19 prevention and response measures and promote positive hygiene practices, safe waste management and ways to mitigate risks of waterborne and other diseases (such as Leishmaniosis). These activities will be conducted during the first four months of the action and supported by distribution of essential COVID-19 hygiene materials (soap and cloth detergents) to beneficiaries most vulnerable to the pandemic.
The action is informed by technical assessments of targeted water and rainwater drainage systems completed by Big Heart Engineers and included under the Documents section of this submission. As such, proposed activities are evidence-based, technically sound and accurately budgeted.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Strengthening the resilience of IDPs and host communities through life-saving activities in the WASH sector.

description.narrative:
By the proposed intervention IYD aims to increase access to sustainable water services in three camps in Harbanoush, Maaret Tamsrin sub-district, the project will support the newly displaced IDPs from Maaret Alnuman to Harbansoh Camps with safe, clean and sustainable drinking water through rehabilitation works which they are proposed in this project including the expansion works for the existing water network to reach the camps around the village who are depending on the water trucking to ensure their daily water need, increase the pumping capacity in the village by equipping the drilled well by the local council with electrical and mechanical equipment such as generator, submersible pump and electrical control panel, also the works includes construction work for generator and pumping rooms in addition to high water tank with capacity of 60 m3 to ensure the proper pressure in the network to let the water reach all the targeted camp, and to ensure the sustainability of the system IYD will form water management committee from the camps residents, and train the committee to establish fees collection system, moreover, IYD will cover the daily need of water by provide the IDP’s camp residents with daily safe and clean water through water trucking at least 35 liters per person per day of chlorinated water for drinking, cooking and domestic purposes for 3 months, during this period IYD will rehabilitate the water pumping system in the camp which will replace the water trucking method in the targeted camp, once the rehabilitation works completed, IYD will cover the operational cost for five months to the established water station which will support the water committee to register all HHs who will benefit from the services and built the tariff system.
And to improve the hygienic conditions in the targeted camps, IYD will provide the IDPs site residents with solid waste collection and 200 locally made waste containers, IYD will address the gap in latrines numbers in the targeted camps by building 30 new latrines blocks (two cells), making them gender sensitive. and address the needs of elderly and disabled beneficiaries, also as complementary with the latrines IYD will provide desludging services and distribute hygiene kits to raise the hygiene awareness for the IDPs as well as prevention for COVID-19, The planned intervention will mainstream protection principles throughout the project cycle by considering the different needs of men, women, boys and girls. Construction of the latrines and the distribution of the water tanks will be consulted with women/men and boys/girls to ensure they serve the communities equitably and consider the specific needs of these groups.
More specifically, the intervention will provide operational cost for two main water stations in Batbu and Kafr Deryan, the operational cost includes (fuel, spare parts, lubricants oil, and water stations and water networks operators’ salaries) for five months, by this activity IYD will ensure provide at least 40 liters per person a day for more than 65,000 individuals in both locations, and to ensure that all beneficiaries will have access to the water networks IYD will rehabilitate the existing water networks by replacing the damaged parts, installation for mechanical parts such as valves and expansion of new water line for the neighborhoods that not covered by the water network. The chlorination process will be under the full control from the IYD staff as well, daily samples from providing water and from the point of use will be taken to do the tests, and daily visit to the HHs to check the storage tanks and containers and ensure clean, this will be done through the water safety plan by IYD.
Finally, it is important to note that all the staff working on these interventions will be given the needed information of any other services in the area (protection, education, livelihood etc.). They will also be trained on safe identification and referrals.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Rehabilitation of WASH infrastructure to ensure IDPs, returnees, and host communities have access to water and sanitation services in northwest Syria.

description.narrative: To improve the living conditions of vulnerable conflict-affected households IDPs, returnees, and host communities, WATAN will implement integrated WASH assistance in western Aleppo governorates. This will ensure that basic needs are addressed at the household level, while also building the capacity of conflict-affected communities to cope with COVID-19. WATAN through this intervention will focus on the urgent needs of 47,833 individuals (11,152 men, 11,534 women, 12,243 boys, and 12,904 girls) (20,534 residents, 12,550 returnees, and 14,749 IDPs) residing in 4 communities (Abin Samaan, Babka, Daret Azza and Kafr Naseh in western Aleppo governorate). The planned intervention will include the following: Water (Abin Samaan, Babka, and Kafr Naseh): This project will cover the rehabilitation of 3 water systems to ensure 20,557 individuals (4793 men, 4957 women, 5263 boys, and 5544 girls) are receiving enough and safe water with at least 45 L /capita/day. Following the rehabilitation, WATAN under this grant will support the operation and maintenance (OampM) cost for 5 months with descending coverage as follow (100% for the first month, then 80%, 60%, 40%, and 20% by the fifth month) This methodology will give the space of the newly established cost recovery to contribute to the OampM under the supervision of WATAN field staff. Thus, confirming the functionality of the cost recovery system and ensuring a smooth exit strategy. Trough the operation and maintenance support, WATAN will pay special attention to the water quality. WATAN will monitor the water quality in two main points, the water source, and the end-use. As the project targets mainly 4 communities (Abin Samaan, Babka, Kafr Naseh, and Daret Azza), Daret Azza was not supported with water activities since after the coordination with the WASH cluster, it was noticed that SECD is covering the water part in the community. Thus, the intervention in Daret Azza is complimentary with SECD intervention in the area. Sanitation, sewer network rehabilitation (Daret Azza, Abin Samaan, and Babka): The project will cover the rehabilitation of three sewer networks in Daret Azza, Abin Samaan, and Babka to ensure 42,831 individuals (9,986 men, 10,328 women, 10,962 boys, and 11,555 girls) have safe access to sanitation infrastructure. As ACU reported, the number of water-borne disease (WBD) cases have sharply increased by 1,278 cases in Atareb sub-district (ACU report 18/04/2020 to 09/05/2020), and by 945 cases in Daret Azza (ACU report 18/04/2020 to 09/05/2020). In addition and as ACU reported, Atareb sub-district has faced an incremental increase in the number of leishmaniases cases by 253 cases and by 39 cases in Daret Azza. This intervention will contribute to decreasing the number of WBD as well as the number of leishmaniasis cases in the area of implementation through ensuring safe disposal of the sludge with no drinking water contamination as a result of and not limited to broken and not functioning sewer system. Moreover, Kafr Naseh was not supported by the rehabilitation of the sewer system as this activity was conducted earlier by IYD. Thus, the activities in Kafr Naseh are complimentary as a result of coordination with the WASH cluster and IYD on the field. Hygiene and COVID-19 response (Kafr Naseh, and Babka): This intervention will pay special attention to the concerns related to COVID-19 outbreak, the response will include the distribution of essential hygiene items (Soap and washing powder) to support 8,074 individuals (1,883 men, 1,947 women, 2,068 boys, and 2,176 girls) for two rounds to tackle hygiene issues and thus contribute hopefully to eliminate the possibility of the outbreak in Jabal Samaan district in Aleppo governorate. Moreover, this project will provision of hygiene promotion sessions which will include messages related to COVID-19 prevention and will be lead by female hygiene promoters where possible and under the supervision of the protection specialist

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Sustainable water and sanitation infrastructure to support IDPs, host community, and returnees in Aleppo and Idleb governorates.

description.narrative:
To improve the living conditions of vulnerable conflict-affected households and emphasize on the prevention measure to COVID 19, Saed Charity in partnership with Minber Alsham are planning to respond to 46,187 (out of which 16,426 Men, 17,519 Female, 6,046 Boys, 6,196 girls, and 412 PwD) IDPs in 20 camps and Kaften community to ensure an improved, sustainable access to WASH services and supplies. In parallel to the WASH cluster strategy in the allocation paper, the aim is to reduce the huge reliance on the costly non-sustainable direct provision water trucking, desludging, etc. towards a more cost-effective cheaper and more efficient response, this is planned to be achieved through connecting the targeted camps and informal settlement to existing nearby water and sanitation system. Furthermore, through this project, SAED and Minber Alsham are aiming to ensure improved access of host communities and IDPs in Kaften community through rehabilitation and operational support for the water system. The water system will be operationalized and maintained by both SAED and Minber Alsham for a period of 10 months for camps and five for Kaften. As the number of IDPs and locations planned are high, SAED and Minber Alsham decided to partner together to ensure a better quality response, output and outcome, relying on the very good WASH knowledge and experience of both agencies taking into account that both SAED and Minber AlSham implemented a successful project together and managed to benefit from previous lessons learnt. During the design phase of the project, both SAED and Minber AlSham kept in mind any future influx of IDPs into the proposed locations, in a summary, we will be able to respond to any increase in numbers. If any gaps arise, SAED will officially inform the WASH cluster to assist and coordinate with other actors in the field to fill the gaps. On average 30-35 ltp/d/ will be provided while during Summer season (July, August, and September) as recommended by the WASH Cluster, IDPs will have access up to 40 lt/p/d.
SAED will target 9 camps with a total population of 17,590 IDPs. While Minber AlSham will target 11 camps with a total population of 24,022 through the following activities: Rehabilitation and operational cost of four water systems Installing and extending water and sanitation network to the camps. Constructing high elevated tanks and rely on gravity distribution to the water points inside camps. Connecting existing sanitation facilities to installed water networks. Hygiene promotion campaigns (following COVID 19 WASH and health clusters recommendation including physical distancing through a mass media campaigns, street panels, WhatsApp sharing methods, etc. will be installed and shared in the premises of the camps as well as the community. Distribution of soap and cloth detergents
15 camps out of the 20 targeted already include an agency who are providing some activities. Therefore, this project proposal does not include a comprehensive package as some activities are covered by other agencies. All activities have been coordinated with present agencies to ensure complementarity and avoid overlaps.
In addition, Minber AlSham will target Kaften community (4,575 people) with rehabilitation and maintenance of the water station and water network in addition to degraded operational cost for 5 months in order to implement a proper cost recovery and tariff system. (Minber AlSham will work closely with the local council and beneficiaries to include them in the design and planning phase of set up. In addition, proper capacity building will take place for stakeholders involved in the tariff system to ensure better managing of resources and water system.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting the most vulnerable groups of people in IDP sites by providing life-saving food assistance and establishing safety voluntary units in camps to protect IDPs from risks of fires and emergencies.

description.narrative:
To improve livelihood conditions of crisis-affected people, preserving their dignity and protecting them from winter severe effects and COVID-19, SCA is planning to fill gaps of basic needs from which 89915 beneficiaries (men 18369– women 20085 – boys 24775 – girls 26686) are suffering in 33 camps under Harim district for 8 months. kindly review Annex 6- list of camps Based on need assessment which SCA conducted, and coordination efforts with different stakeholders by data cross-checking of all implemented and planned response by humanitarian partners, taking into consideration the objectives and conditions of this allocation, SCA through this project will implement the following interventions:
-CCCM Component: The proposed interventions aim to reinforce alert status, protection and fire response in 33 camps from the most dangerous IDP sites in terms of fire in Harem district (Please refer to annex number 6) in which 89915 beneficiaries through developing systems and initial response levels of fires which were developed by firefighting experts and through reviewing international agencies' experiences in different crisis-affected areas which include (Please refer to annex 5 – Executive Summary): -Level 0: Raising awareness of IDP sites population, especially women for fires, its causes and protection ways besides distributing 19114 firefighting blankets, in average one blanket per one beneficiary household and guiding women on how to use them. -Level 1: Establishing 45 firefighting units (points) in 33 camps and equipping them by necessary tools and equipment of firefighting, besides establishing Safety and Firefighting Voluntary Units through training 1199 young men who will be selected carefully to have 75 persons from camps population well-trained to deal with fires and firefighting equipment. Please also review annex 25 CCCM dashboard for targeted camps. -Level 2: Constant coordination with Civil Defense to deal with huge fires and providing support. -FSL Component: Through proposed interventions, SCA will meet 70 % of food needs for 1864 newly displaced households and live in 6 camps out of the 33 above-mentioned camps (Please refer to Annex 1) who suffer food insecurity, in which SCA previously implemented the first stage of food response through distributing cooked meals and emergency kits in the four last months, food needs will be met for 8 regular months through distributing 14912 standard food kits according to FSL cluster standards, from which 9549 IDPs (men 1924 – women 2138 – boys 2677 – girls 2810) will benefit. In order to reinforce COVID-19 protection, soap will be distributed on beneficiaries in average 750 g soap to each beneficiary household monthly. The proposed interventions in this project were designed according to FSL and CCCM clusters guidelines and in line with current allocation objectives and guidance in terms of activity and intervention integration approach, besides risks management and maintain high levels of accountability towards affected population, SCA guarantees applying all planned procedures related to previous issues which are enrolled in this project proposal and its annexes. SCA will ensure the commitment of all staff, labors and related contractors to Humanitarian Principles, Codes of Conduct and PSEA Code of Conduct and Child Protection

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Reduce the impact of the negative effect for the winter season for the IDP's living into informal settlements in Aleppo and Idleb governorate

description.narrative: The proposed project is designed to respond to the needs related to winterization intervention for the IDPs (3100 HH, 20,220 beneficiaries) who are settled in informal settlements in Aleppo governorate (Atareb Sub District) and Idleb Governerate (Dana Sub District) which is classified as high need sub district in the allocation paper for both allocation strategic objectives, by providing the most urgent life-saving winterization intervention which is in line with ASO2 under SA2. The assistance will take the people centered approach taking into consideration equity in access, quality, responsiveness and participation, efficacy and resilience the intervention can be summarized as the following: - Under FSL Cluster: the project will cover the distribution of Food Rations (1500 FR) fpr 1500 HH settled in 14 camp as per cluster guideline for 6 months. This activity will target all beneficiaries in the targeted informal settlements. These food rations will be distributed once a month and for 6 months by informing the targeted HHs about the timing and the location as well, taking into consideration the COVID-19 preventive measures in addition to deliver the FRs to the HHs that are headed by females, contain PwD or children in order to ensure their safety and dignity as well. This intervention is classified under ASO2 Cluster Specific Objective. - Under SNFI Cluster: Project will cover the distribution of stoves, heating fuel ( for 3 months), thermal blankets and plastic sheets according to the SNFI guideline for 3100 HH settled in 23 camps. The stoves will be delivered on HH level and ATAA will ensure that the stoves are installed in a proper way and put in a safe location in each tent to ensure better effectiveness. The heating fuel which is Olive bit/Pomace will be distributed for 3 months (three rounds) to cover the winter season and each HH will receive 250 kg/month. Each HH will also receive 5 single thermal blankets along with 2 plastic sheets as one-off distribution in the project period to increase the efficiency of the heating that is being secured by the distributed stoves and fuel. These items will be distributed by informing the targeted HHs about the timing and the location as well, taking into consideration the COVID-19 mitigating and preventive measures and also deliver the materials to the HHs which are headed by females, PwD and children (door-to-door distribution) in order to ensure their safety and dignity as well. This intervention is classified under ASO2 Cluster Specific Objective. - Under CCCM Cluster: The project will cover the enhancement of the capacity of the camps' representatives in the targeted informal settlements to prevent, mitigate and respond to the fire incidents by conducting FGDs and awareness-raising sessions with the camp management and beneficiaries taking into practice and account the COVID-19 preventive measures during the awareness-raising sessions and FGD's along with developing fire warden systems in the targeted camps. Additionally, the project will ensure the provision of fire extinguishers and fire blankets to enhance the capacity of the people on firefighting by providing them with the needed materials in the targeted informal settlements in case of any fire incident occurring. This intervention is classified under ASO2 Cluster Specific Objective this intervention will target 3100 HH settled in 23 camps ATAA took into consideration during project design phase, that the project and proposed activities are cost efficient to ensure the impact of the intervention. Additionally, the implementation of the project will be started immediately while ATAA have launched the procurement process following the approved procurement policy by OCHA especially for the seasonal assistant.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of access to safe and quality education for conflict affected children in IDP settlements in NWS.

description.narrative:
With the Syrian conflict entering its 10th year, the humanitarian situation in northwestern Syria continues to deteriorate, impacting all life aspects of the Syrian families. The outbreak of the Coronavirus epidemic have added yet another dimension to the crisis and increased the burden on the vulnerable families while they strive to acquire their most basic needs. The negative impact of the pandemic is amplified in areas of large gatherings such as camps, informal settlements, and schools where the ability to apply social distancing rules is severely limited and high level of vulnerability prevents households from investing in precautionary measures such as increasing the use of hygiene items/facilities and Personal Protection Equipment (PPE).
Therefore, PIN plans through the proposed project to cover up to 10 camps with a package of assistance that is aimed at responding to the education needs of said camps in a qualitative and safe manner. In brief, PIN proposes the provision of a blended online and physical education to 2,600 school-aged children in 10 IDP camps, to adequately respond to the COVID-19 created needs with a tailor-made approach. PIN will take on providing students and teachers with the essential teaching and learning materials as well as recreational materials. PIN will cover the learning centers operational costs, including COVID-19 prevention materials, and fuel for heating during the winter months in order to keep learning centers well-functioning and to create a safe and child-friendly environment. PSS will be a fundamental part of the project aiming to improve the well-being and learning capacity of children and teachers, who are not only traumatized by the war, but experiencing many new stress factors and serious impact of the virus. All these services will be provided through the blended approach that combines cautious physical attendance with the distance learning module that PIN has already established across its education portfolio, and allows a prompt shift between the methodologies when needed, adapting to the context.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting the Immediate and Critical Measures for the Most Vulnerable Children in Schools

description.narrative:
The deteriorating situation in NW Syria is weaking the community ability to seriously consider the prevention measures against COVID-19 pandemic. Also, recent reports showed increasing numbers in infections among population while the estimated number of people at high COVID risk is 2.9 million. the project is focusing on maintaining and enhancing children access to education as a response to COVID-19 pandemic and prevent children dropping out schools due to uncertain circumstances of the education through (i) implement safe school protocols (COVID-19 prevention and control) and (ii) adapt the distance learning modality benefiting 20,000 school aged children (7-18 years old- Boys 9,528 Girls 10,472 ~ 1,000 CwD) and 1,600 teachers and caregivers (Men 788 , Women 812) in 20 schools and 77 TLSs in Harim and Idleb districts (Idleb governorate)
The project will increase the capacity of education services to provide COVID-19 safe learning environment through implementing prevention protocols in 20 schools for 17,500 school aged children (7-18 years old, 8,278 Boys, 9,222 Girls, 1,000 CwD) and 600 teacher (288 Men, 312 Women) by providing the required resources such as cleaning and sterilizing material, PPEs for teachers, and Water for schools’ WC blocks for the second semester of the academic year 2020/2021. Along with improving the WC blocks conditions by rehabilitation / expansion of 12 schools’ WC blocks and establishing 18 new WC blocks for TLSs in 9 camps Since the proper and adequate WASH facilities and services are a key factor in maintaining appropriate IPC measures. The WCs block will be gender separated and will include dedicated units for CwDs
On the other hand the project will support the Teachers, Children, and Parents to adapt the distance learning modality benefiting 2,500 school aged children (7-18 years old, 1,250 Boys, 1,250 Girls, 100 CwD) and 1,600 adults (Teachers and Caregivers) (788 Men, 812 Women). The multilevel support will ensure achieving the designated outcomes of the distance learning. Starting with the teachers, the teachers will undergo an online training program to introduce them to the new teaching methods that is used in the distance learning and introduce them to the softwares that is used along with other subjects detailed in the relevant activity in the logical framework. 20 training groups will target 600 teachers (288 Men, 312 Women). Children from the targeted schools will be selected based on the needs and vulnerability criteria and based on the education modality in their schools (face-to-face or distance learning) if a school had many confirmed COVID-19 cases and turned the physical education modality to the distancing modality. The project will provide internet vouchers to the most vulnerable children to allow them to continue receiving their online classes. In order to ensure that the children are committed to attend their lessons online, dedicated education supervisors will be assigned to follow up and measure the education outcomes along with the teachers and schools’ administrations. For the caregiver the education supervisor will conduct a caregiver engagement program in order to support children education at home level through enabling the caregiver to follow up, encourage, and support their children and ensure that the caregivers understand the importance of education for their children.
Bonyan will achieve the project objective through a series of specific activities and processes, taking into account accountability to affected-people, protection mainstreaming and GBV/PSEA, risk analysis and mitigation, tight monitoring and evaluation processes, and effective coordination with all stakeholders, as well as, a coherent exit strategy that contributes to sustainable results of the project.

title.narrative: Enhancing safe access to Education services with Covid-19 preventive measures in Dana and Darkosh sub-districts

description.narrative:
This project is going to provide a package of education services with innovative modalities that enhance safe access to the most vulnerable groups of children to continue receiving their formal and non-formal education services. Non-formal education will target 500 of most vulnerable children aged 7-8 years who are newly displaced without any access to education during this academic year in 5 IDPs sites and their parents aren’t sending them to the schools off camps fearing of Covid-19 and we selected these ages because children at this age supposed to be in grades 1amp2 which considered the entry grades for the children to formal education and this will help them getting the basic skills in the main subjects(English – Arabic – Math)to rejoin the formal education after completing the catch-up classes at the end of the project through contracting with 15 non-formal mobile teachers to provide catch-up classes(on two rounds),each round will last for 3.5 months to 500(260 boys amp 240 girls) most vulnerable children and implementing a series of Covid-19 preventive a and mitigating measures in 23 opened not supported schools that provide formal education services and the teachers are working voluntarily ,16 schools in Dana sub-district and 7 schools in Darkosh sub-district including (establish a Covid-19 response team in each school consists of head of school -2 security guards – 2 cleaners and pay their incentives for 5 months and train 453 teachers(239 men amp 214 women) and supporting staff in 23 schools on preventive measures of Covid-19 and how to make referrals to suspected cases and CP basics and safeguarding, distribute cleaning and sterilization kits to 23 schools for 5 months(till the end of this academic year), provide PPEs kits to 453 teachers (239 men amp 214 women) in 23 schools on monthly bases, distribute PPEs kits to 12,736 children(5751 boys amp 6985 girls) in 23 schools for once, conduct daily and weekly cleaning and disinfection to 23 schools, provide awareness sessions to 1000 parents(610 men amp 390 women)and 12,736 children(5751 boys amp 6985 girls) including 184 children with disabilities on the preventive measures of Covid-19, conduct referral pathways from schools to specialized health , protection and other services, set up safety and evacuation plans in schools and train the teachers and children on them, contract with internet supplier to provide the schools with monthly internet packages for the children whose classes are quarantined at homes after having confirmed positive case in their classroom to ensure the continuity of their education during the quarantining period.
SoP is the lead and will be responsible for implementing the project activities in the targeted 7 schools in Darkosh and SOP amp SCA( sub-IP) will be jointly responsible for implementing all the project activities in 16 schools and SCA will be responsible for implementing all the project activities in the 5 targeted IDPs sites in Dana sub-district with close coordination between the teams of SoP and SCA in Turkey and Syria in the implementation stage and for more details about the roles (kindly, see the scope of work in the attached documents)
